title: WSDC 2024 R6 - Japan vs Brazil
description:
This House would introduce a governmental basic income for all artists, rather than offering governmental fellowships and grants to certain artists upon application.

Basic income for artists is a policy in which governments provide all artists with a regular, unconditional sum of money to ensure a basic standard of living, regardless of income or employment status.

Fellowships and grants are programs in which governments or organizations provide artists with financial support, often for a specific project or period of time, based on merit or need. These funds are typically awarded through a competitive application process.

3-0 Japan Wins
motion: This House would introduce a governmental basic income for all artists, rather than offering governmental fellowships and grants to certain artists upon application.

argument_units.text: Art is a source of expression, a source of happiness for artists and people. But at the same time, in the status quo, art is an inherently extremely fragile profession. Because under the status quo, when there are only grants and fellowships, art is a lucky opportunity that is only granted to the richest, most lucky individuals who manage to get through these applications.
We believe on side proposition that art should be accessible, it should be enjoyed by all individuals, including those at the bottom of the social ladder. So proud to propose.

My arguments for today is firstly on increased accessibility of art, and secondly, why fellowships hurt minorities disproportionately and why we're able to benefit those minorities on our side. But before that two pieces on framing. Firstly, what does the implementation of this basic income policy look like? We think that this basically looks like providing less than the basic income and only the basic living expenses for these people. The implication of this is that there will be no irrational opt-in from actors who don't really want to pursue art. Because this is not a huge grant. We are providing them with the basic necessities that they need to keep on living. The people who will benefit from this policy are the people in the status quo who want to pursue art. But secondly, what is the definition of artist and who are the artists who will be funding? We think that there are two criteria. Firstly, that these people will basically have to have some, be making some sort of income from art. But secondly, that they have to be making art at some level of consistency. The implication of this is that this person who just made one song like 20 years ago and has not made any songs since is simply not going to be able to continuously get money from this policy.

With that then, on to our first argument of increased accessibility on art. There are two layers to this argument. First layer, why under fellowship and grant programs in the status quo, not many people can access art in the first place. This is simply due to the fact that currently the art industry is very, very competitive, and you have to take down lots of competition in order to even get these grants in the first place, which are incredibly limited. You do not know who gets these grants, because, especially so, since in order to get a grant, you need to pass these application processes. What that means is that inherently, people who had access to money to go to art schools, who had money to access good paint brushes, good paint, who had money to be able to have the capacity to have time to even create these art pieces or create great art pieces to send to the application process. Only those rich and very privileged individuals can get access to these grants and fellowships on our side of the house. We think this is also extremely difficult for people to just balance the application process with other things like applying for your side jobs for example. So the implication of this is that poor people, especially those who need to do multiple jobs at the same time, are very very disadvantaged when it comes to applying for these applications because they cannot produce good enough quality art to be the people at the top. Note that there's also no guarantee, again, even if you as a poor person are able to get a grant the first time, there's no guarantee that you'll be able to get a grant the second time and the third time because it is so competitive. On that side, no thank you, we think that because of this, on that side, many people have to quit art in the first place because their paintings do not go through the application process and they're not even able to get out into the public sphere. We think that there are also people who pursue art because they're so passionate about art, but because they continue to pursue this, they are only depleting money from their pockets and going into the cycle of eternal poverty, not being able to get any money whatsoever. This looks like the people who create mangas in Japan. We think that there are many people who like to pursue mangas but simply cannot get enough income to sustain their basic necessities and they keep but and yet they still keep on going. On the comparative, on our side, under our policy, everyone is able to get money. Every single artist is able to get money. So on to later to them. What is the impact of this? The impact of this is twofold. Firstly, everyone who wants to pursue art can pursue art. And note that this is incredibly important, Josh, because the characterization of these artists are that these people inherently want to pursue art because you wouldn't be an artist if you didn't like doing art, right? So on that side, when we're actively taking away the opportunities to succeed, it's incredibly mentally harming and an inherent contradiction to that entire identity as an artist when we think that we are able to give them the opportunities that they deserve to be given on our side of the house. But secondly, we think that we also are able to give money to those who continue to pursue art. We think that on either side, due to passion, people will continue to pursue art. We think that we are uniquely able to give them the money and give them the basic necessities to be able to sustain themselves on our side of the house. Before I go into my second argument, what do you mean by accessing art? We think that accessing art is basically the ability for artists to be able to make profit from art, to be able to succeed from art, to be able to get self-sustainability from art.

Second argument then, why fellowships hurt minorities disproportionately. There are three mechanisms of this. Firstly, we think that in this stage, the government and the people who grant these fellowships is an amalgamation from people from majority communities, right? These people have intrinsic biases that lean towards that majority community. For example, in Japan, that would be the very rich elitist at the top. But you think that secondly, the fact that there's no objective metric to decide whether one piece of art is good or bad means that people can very easily weaponize this lack of objectivity and discriminate against minority artists. This looks like, for example, in a very white-centric community, we think that if you can have a portrait of an Asian with a portrait of a white person, even if the skills and the art style that were used were the same, we think that the white person or the portrait of the white person is more likely to be granted access and to be granted fellowship. But thirdly, we think that even if the minorities are able to get through this application process, we think that they'll still cater to the majority perspective. We think that this is because they're dependent on the majority people for that funding. What that means is that when people want to make movies about rape victims, they will not really depict the full brutality of it, and will not really blame men for it, and we think that they will downplay this to a significant extent. This also looks like whitewashed paintings of racism that exist in the state's core, and can only get publicity under that brutal policy. The implication of this is that minorities cannot get runs, and even if they do, it's only for artists who downplay their social message. So what is the importance of this? The importance of this is twofold. Firstly, on principle, we think that this is principally wrong. We think that this is an inherently arbitrary way you are born, and what status you are born, so it is wrong for the state to actively endorse discrimination against certain groups of people. Just in the same way it is not good for the state to actively fund white schools over black schools or white schools over Latino schools. We think that it is simply wrong to take this policy or to further the continuation of this policy. This policy should be for all. But secondly, we think that minority art in and of itself is extremely important, especially for those minorities, because it is simply very liberating for them to be able to express their anger, to express their oppression. We think that at the point in which the state is not allowing them to do this, we think that we should take this policy that allows minorities to at least be able to self-express themselves and make an income from it. But lastly, we think that there are many societal implications of this. The fact that literary arts like the colour purple or music from artistic choice of art spread huge societal messages to the rest of society, we think that on that side, that is at the point in which you're not able to get the societal narratives out in the open. For all those reasons, proud to propose. Thank you.

title: WSDC 2018 R7: India VS China
description: This House regrets the Belt and Road Initiative.
motion: This House regrets the Bell and Road Initiative.

argument_units.text: Every time Sri Lanka's ex-president turned to China for a loan for his ambitious port, China said yes. Yes, though feasibility studies disapproved. Yes, though frequent lenders like India had rejected the plan. Yes, though Sri Lanka's debt was already ballooning under Mr Rajapaksha.

When, predictably, Sri Lanka's government struggled to repay the debt, they were forced to hold Pan-China, the port, for 99 years. From Ethiopia to Kazakhstan, where Chinese money was once celebrated, today protests erupt against these failed projects. We say it was just one road, then it's a dead end. What do we stand for?

The Belt and Road Initiative, or BRI, refers to China's infrastructural projects throughout Europe, Asia, and Africa. This includes railways, bridges, and seaports to make two passages that give China infrastructure projects throughout Europe, Asia and Africa. This includes railways, bridges and seaports to make passages that give China direct access to 70 nations. Along the historic Silk Road, as a part of Xi Jinping's grand strategy, what are the key characteristics of this? It is financed through billions in debt that is not conditional on economic or political reform. Debt that is funneled through Chinese state banks and China-run AIIB, making it subject to purely and exclusively Chinese oversight. These construction projects are also exclusively run by Chinese state-run firms with Chinese workers. If a loan is not repaid, China will forgive a part of the debt in exchange for ownership of the infrastructure like we saw in Sri Lanka. What is the context of this debate? Over the last five years, China could have gone down two roads. They could have worked with existing systems of development using their increased influence in the World Bank, Asian Development Bank, the BRICS Bank to strengthen the systems of collaborative lending, or they could have gone at it alone where the terms are dictated by their self-interest. We regret that China didn't take the first road and took the latter road. It's not that we think China is malicious, but that they are self-interested. And it makes sense for them to go do what gives them the most soft power. But this debate is about whether we, as the recipients of these projects and the world community, think that they have created a net harm. We say yes.

Three arguments. First, the Belt and Road Initiative is the road to economic harm to host nations. Two, the Belt and Road Initiative is the road to upsetting the international power, balance of power. And third, the BRI is the road to entrenching in liberal regimes. First, why is the BRI the road to economic harm for its recipient nations? These projects are funded through loans. Given how projects are run by Chinese corporations with Chinese workers, nations should have already been cautious about the debt. But the BRI targets small and economically vulnerable nations that are unable to reject Chinese loans when it comes to mounting pressure. They fear that non-participation will cause that the trade deals that China will have will be something that they lose out of trade deals that China will have will be something that they lose out of, and that they will lose these generous Chinese aid. So when Beijing comes knocking on Mongolia's door and threatens to end their cooperation on tuberculosis in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, Mongolia isn't really begging for the bridges that get built in their nation. When these nations take this step, default is the most likely reality. Why? Because the speciality of Chinese loans is that they don't require economic reform. So the governments take on loans, but don't rein in on spending and then struggle to repay them. Their infrastructure, set up under the BRI, also does not pay for itself, because they are often white elephants, vanity projects of leaders that duplicate existing infrastructure. That's why when Prime Minister Rajapaksa builds a second Sri Lankan ad board, which he names after himself with the money from the BRI, he saddles the country with debt and the world's emptiest ad board. What are the consequences of this default? China could graciously forgive this debt and so generously take over the infrastructure but that means they have control over ports, roads and airports.

In fact, this is the deliberate Chinese contingency plan that in the worst case, they take back their sunk costs using your ports and your airports to dump their products into your country and then they use those very resources to extract your natural resources and take it out through your ports. We've seen debt defaults in developed nations like Greece fracturing the spirit of the people and leaving people who aren't employed. Imagine this in Kenya. Crucially, default in the wake of an unfinished project is devastating to other countries in the BRI. You can't build a road from China to Egypt if Kenya in the middle defaults. That's why this would invalidate anyone's investment because when one nation defaults, it puts the entire project at the risk of default. In the comparison, the alternative is borrowing from multilateral institutions like the Asian Development Bank, Br the comparison, the alternative is borrowing from multilateral institutions like the Asian Development Bank, BRICS Bank or the African Development Bank. Sure, China might have inflated the total amount of debt, but all debt is in good debt. What does multilateral debt look like instead? No one country has exclusive power. Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa each have the same equal share of 20% in the BRICS Bank. In the Asia Development Bank, the US and Japan account for 15% while China, India, Canada and Korea have the rest. Maritime lenders each want their money back and use their power to check each other. So even if independently they are self-invested, together they can't design a system that cedes monopoly over infrastructure to one country. So default is mutual loss in such an investment for the investor and the host nation. So in each of them asking for their money back and holding these nations accountable, they lend with sustainable preconditions.

We regret the BRI for being a regime that is designed to prey on the most economically vulnerable nations. Second, why is the BRI the road to upsetting the international balance of power? BRI uniquely empowers the Chinese global hegemony for that.

Oftentimes the countries that utilize the BRI like Kazakhstan and Tajikistan are connected together rather than simply being connected to China. This allows for intra-country trade on our side of the house.

How would that have happened without the BRI? This is a lie, and so far, the status and quotas continue to remain the same between these nations. The unifying factor of the BRI is not that nations are linked with each other, but overwhelmingly linked with China. We regret that. The BRI uniquely empowers the Chinese global hegemony. If the projects are successful, it entrenches their military. The corridors are designed to allow Chinese troops to mobilize at the borders of any nation and scare them into submission. But remember, the project passes through territory that is undisputedly disputed, especially border areas like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor that passes through Indian territory that's claimed by India. When China is already incursing on this region, it's unacceptable. It allows them to force smaller countries into trade deals. When the giant that you owe a billion dollars to says, you can't join that trade deal, better join this treated area, that's a choice that vulnerable nations can't make. Further, like we explained, the deliberate plan is to allow default and takeover infrastructure. In such a world, China has unprecedented influence over global trade and over Western nations. Because if China controls major trade routes and hubs, controls Pakistan, Sri Lanka and South Africa's hubs, then Nigeria, America, India, all of these regions are economically hurt at the point which they can hold that port as leverage and say we will not allow you to access this. The BRI crowds out regional powers and regional cooperation. We see this when Philippines was pushing for ASEAN multilateralism but then had to cede into the BRI. Now, all without the BRI, the US, China and regional superpowers check each other. incentives in China? Our very first speech has reasons why these conditions are basic bare minimum things you need in order to ensure that the loan gets repaid. Unless Sri Lanka checks their massive public spending, they're never paying back the 68 billion dollar debt that they have to China. They needed to respond to that somewhere in their two speeches if they wanted to make that response and that point of information. AASAI is the one with sustainable loans which actually work for countries. On the third flash, does the belt help the most repressed in the world? Quickly, let's deal with their funky argument on benefits to China. In an interesting way, this hurts India. Three reasons why. Firstly, because we're really scared of China having military control all around us, which means we need to spend a lot. Which means money doesn't go into healthcare. Which means money doesn't go into education. Also because of border violations we told you about, it hurts our ability to keep our soldiers not dying. Furthermore, on weighing, India will have more people than China will after the BRI is over. Which means also, the more work. Which means we'll means more vulnerable. We took that argument at its best, panel. Now let's get on to the actual debate on the comparative for illiberal regimes. They told you, oh these will be illiberal all the time. Here's the thing, panel. This is a debate about countries like Philippines, countries like Kenya. It's not true that you're either a dictatorship or Denmark. There are people in the middle who actually can change if you incentivise them to do so. What their side does is literally give them an incentive to become worse when Duterte sits next to Xi Jinping and gets no condemnation for slaughtering 20,000 people in a war on drugs in his country. That is a world where you incentivise them to go further. Not that they don't benefit the people by giving them loans either. Because the loans aren't going to the people if it's truly a strong man who doesn't care. We are the only side that helps the most repressed in society. We are the only side that looked at developing nations, didn't coerce them into half-billed deals that would rob them of their resources, and actually allowed them to prosper. We were the only side that maintained a balance of power. If it's a one loan, we think it's a dead end.

Based on the analysis coming from Team India, it seems like all countries besides China are run by three-year-old idiots that will drive their country into the ground with no foresight of whether loans exist. We don't think that was actually the debate, and we think that countries are far more important and far more able to understand the risks associated with the BRI compared to what they said.
I have two simple questions. Firstly, does the BRI benefit partner countries? And secondly, is the BRI better than alternatives?

So first, let's talk about if the BRI is better than alternatives. And we told you that the BRI was uniquely considerate because it drew off evocative cultural symbolism and was extended as a form of soft power. This is exactly why China has been spending millions of dollars promoting BRI stories, promoting BRI outreach, and letting the world know about it, because it precisely is a form of soft power. And because it is a form of soft power, soft power cares about publicity far more than extortionary economic deals that happen behind closed doors. That was the comparative of this debate. Their response to this was, China always wants to seize maximum power, right? We agree. But in this particular instance, China is far more willing to trade off economic profit with cultural perceived advancement. So without the BRI, China would be likely to negotiate bilateral deals that focus on maximum financial extraction. That's far worse, and that was the comparative they had to deal with. Then they came up in third and had this weird response that countries can negotiate better in bilateral deals. I'm sorry, but I don't think Kenya has very much leveraging power against the country that has the second most GDP in the world and will threaten to get rid of it if they don't agree. We think we needed a better response than that.

But secondly, we told you that if China is so intent on establishing hegemony, if you don't let them establish it through the BRI, they will establish it through other, far more pernicious forms of sharp power. Their only response was a glib, we would get that too. Yes, we'd like to prevent every bad thing in the world that ever happened, including poverty, but it's not what the debate is about. Because without the existence of the BRI, China would be far more likely to pursue these alternatives. We told you that as insofar as the BRI exists, it therefore means that China doesn't have to rely on these other means we think that's far better. Then they said, well, we rebutted ourselves because we said China cares about its publicity. Yes, they care about its publicity, but only seen it so far as they're dealing with soft power, which is particularly only available on our side of the house. Because sharp power is intrinsically bad to publicity, they don't care about it as much in that instance. This therefore means that without this system of government, any alternative would be China pursuing far more draconian policies on their side of the house.

Secondly, let's talk about whether or not the BRI benefits partner countries. Because we gave you five structural reasons as to why China would be better in incentives. They responded to one of them. They responded to the one about how they are in a uniquely good position. Their response was, poverty isn't really peaceful. I think that's premised on the idea that these countries are already prosperous. We don't think that's the case. Because if you look at countries like Kazakhstan, like Tajikistan, those countries were already in poverty before the BRI came around. It was only after they came in, they connected them to the world, that they were actually able to prosper. But more importantly, we told you about the trade incentives on our side of the house. That because China wants to trade with these countries, it means that they simply gain nothing from bankrupting them and putting people into unemployment. We told you about how to test of soft power. We told you how oftentimes they have internal priorities. We told you about the flexibility of their loans, no response to any of these reasons. But more importantly, there were tangible benefits on our side of the house. And it's not enough for them to say we had no examples, because we clearly did. We told you about the inter-country trade that had happened on our side of the house, because of the roads that link Djibouti to Ethiopia. Because contrary to what they say, you don't need to simply be linked to China for your roads to work. As long as you're linked to nations around you, it still lets you trade with other nations. No response to that. But secondly, we told you that it allows for the integration of economies. What does that mean? It means that even parts that are created in China are assembled in places like Kazakhstan because these types of countries can coexist and use their competitive advantage. What did they tell us? They told us two broad ideas. The first one on dumping, and the second one on loans.

What did we tell you about dumping? We had four responses. Number one, that China has an incentive to keep industries afloat because you can't buy cheap goods if you're unemployed and have zero income. But secondly, you enable countries and industries to grow because roads systematically work both ways. And that means that when the country's on their side of the house and they compare it where no roads exist, it's far worse. But thirdly, because the products that China dump are categorically different from the products that these countries and industries produce, what does it mean? It means China primarily dumps things like cheap technology, things that these countries generally don't produce. But fourthly, we told you, consumer access is particularly important. Because when a smartphone is actually accessible for a poor man in a rural community, it means that you can now, for the very first time, allow them to improve their standard of living, no response to any of that. Their only response was, well, first China tries to monopolize, and then it raises prices in the long run. Here's the problem. When you raise prices, local industries can now compete again. This means that China, if it raises prices, will make sure that local industries can grow up. No response to that.

The second idea we heard was the idea of loans. We have three responses. Number one, if loans are so extortionary, if there were so many clear-cut examples of loans, countries clearly wouldn't voluntarily sign into this type of agreement. The reason why is because countries benefit themselves and they're clearly able to benefit. But secondly, just because you default on loans doesn't mean China benefits. Because China clearly still loses millions of dollars on a failed project that they cannot recoup even if they claim a port. But thirdly, let's say defaults exist on both sides of the house. Defaults are far better on our side. Why? Because China is far more lenient under circumstances of default. Because when you default on our side, China will just say, it's okay, we'll just claim this port. On their side, what default happens when you go to multilateral banks, is they do things like impose austerity, which is far worse, which hurts citizens the most, and means that normal people are hit the most. Before that, sure.
China has a subsidy regime, huge agricultural services, and an oversupply that you spoke of. How is this free competition between Djibouti and China?

We never said it was free competition. The structural incentives mean that if you want other countries to buy your products, those people need the money to buy your products. So if you try to flood their industries and destroy everything they have, they won't be able to purchase your products even if they're cheap.

Okay, let's deal with what they said about alternatives. Because their only response was multilateral banks are better. We gave you four responses to this, again. Number one, we told you that in the context of an isolationist West and an insular EU, investment would have never come to landlocked countries of Eastern Europe. Secondly, we told you that even in places where multilateral banks were available, that it was simply infeasible, because they impose things like stringent environmental regulations that make projects economically infeasible. Secondly, we think they're far worse. Why? Because they seem to claim that condition A is far better. Unfortunately, condition A is a euphemism for structural adjustment. It is a euphemism for austerity that hurts citizens the most and cuts welfare spending. But thirdly, they say it crowds out other people without really explaining the mechanism. Why? That is simply not true. In places like Southeast Asia, Japan still outspends China. In Central Asia, the ADB and the Asian Bank also compete alongside China. And here's where we directly respond to what they said. Because they tell us the World Bank funded millions of dollars. Yes, the vast majority of that funding only occurred after the Belt and Road Initiative. Why? Because on our side, there is now an incentive to compete. Because if you don't give loans out, it's seen as losing the opportunity to gain that land. So what happens now is there is a race to the bottom. People make loans far more accessible. Because on their side of the house, the places they're talking about never get those loans. At the end of the day, what otherwise would have happened to these types of countries is they wouldn't have loans. There would be no incentive to outreach to them and people would be stuck in the very conditions they were born in. Conditions of abject poverty. We provided the ability for people to get out of these areas and that's why we were proud to oppose.

Panel, I think India's case fell when they misread the motion. Because today's debate was not about everything wrong with China's foreign policy and economic deals around the world. Today's debate was about the Belt and Road Initiative. And that distinction was quite important. Because even on their side, China is expansionist. They want to take over these countries.

But they're going to do it through sharp power rather than through soft power and economic deals. The countries on their side are still desperate and impoverished, so instead of doing it through the Belt and Road Initiative, which is multilateral, they'll do bilateral deals with China, they'll go do the AIIB by themselves, and they'll end up in the economic destitution that they talk about. Because ultimately, China's incentives cannot be inflated with the Belt and Road Initiative. This was a special project that was created by China to improve their image, one that meant that they had to be modern, because they didn't want to ruin its very own purpose. Economic deals exist on both sides. On our side, they're a little bit better, because China cares about its appearance.

I'm going to look at this debate through two vectors. Firstly, the countries that are within the BRI, and secondly China itself. Firstly then, on the countries within the BRI, we explained to you that we uniquely brought you development. Things like roads that can allow for inter-African and inter- Asian trade. Tourism, technological and cultural exchange to over 4.4 billion people. Access to consolidated markets like stock markets that countries like Azerbaijan would never have on their own. Electricity and cheap technology to the people who otherwise are never able to gain access to it because the infant industries within their own countries are never able to develop it. That is why we told you examples like the China-Pakistan, can generate $62 billion every year.

Importantly then, why were the responses inadequate? Firstly, they told us that some countries default. But sure, that is true. But the comparative on your side is that they default on AIIV loans on themselves, but they don't get the support from China because China doesn't need to rectify their own image. Secondly, they told us that China was extortionist and hegemonic. Problem is, they are too on your side. And importantly, throughout this entire debate, the comparative needed not to rely on the BRI versus the best possible case scenario of any sort of loan from some magical institution that is multilateral and going to give you the best of deals. Because even if we took them at their best case, when we engaged our grounds like the SAPs from the IMF, we told you that the exploded economies of Chile and Greece probably mean that those are not suitable for most countries. Their response was, this is minimum standards. But we think that just laughs in the face of the people who are dying within those economies because they were ruined by even the most best and glorious actors on their side. Then, they told us that dictatorships are going to be perpetuated. But the unfortunate reality is dictators exist on both sides. And this they told us that dictatorships are going to be perpetuated. But the unfortunate reality is dictators exist on both sides. And this is very simple. Why? The thought calculus of a dictator goes as such. On one side, I get loans, but no power. On the other side, I get no loans, but I get power. They always choose power, and thus dictatorships existed on both sides. That was why it was extremely pertinent that our side was able to bring the development, to actually help the individuals within these countries. And we told you that even when it comes on the metric of dictatorship and democracy, the best way you get democracy is when you can bolster the middle class, one that on their side is impoverished and starving and never gets access to the benefits of the Belt Road Initiative.

But ultimately, let's talk about China. Because India may want to paint China black, but we think that there are certain areas that are improved by this policy because the discriminated minorities like the leaders in Xinjiang are actually able to get economic improvement because they're utilized within these fields and note that if you really want to get snarky right China has a bigger population than India so even if you want to get on those terms we think we outweigh them because we have like 200 million more people but ultimately and at the end end of today's debate, the comparative is this. On our side, China has unique incentives, because the Belt Road Initiative is a soft power that they need to retain. It is an image that they have crafted that they want to keep. On their side, that image dissolves. But the economic interests stay the same, and they're likely going to conscript the countries around them and turn them into the destitution that India had pulled us about. Ultimately, their case in itself, because the only alternative or comparative we saw was one that was much more bleak and one that never cared about its reputation, we were very proud to oppose.

It's just strategic and extra. You know, China just wanted that piece of Pakistan, that piece of Sri Lanka, so they took it. The Chinese empire and its 2,000 years of glory have lived through the Silk Road, so we need to empower the Chinese empire again. For some reason, this is the case that side opposition brought, while simultaneously they accused us of being scam-mongering, accused us of saying China was malicious and of being xenophobic in the way the West has been. We don't understand. If it is true that these are the kinds of

intents that China has, that this is the self-interest that they pursue, why then will they be celebrating the OBOI? Because throughout this debate, they conceded in the first, when they arrived at the start, that it is something that intrinsically can be regretted, just wanted to push for the comparative. We'll talk power. It gives you a lot of nuanced material across the picture.

First we say that when you have an immense amount of debt, the trillions of debt that China pushes these nations into, that it has control over these nations. That it takes away ports in general regions and gets to hold the entire world hostage. But it says if you want to trade in South Asia and the Indian Ocean, you have to go through us. That it mobilizes its military instantaneously, if it wants to, to scare nations into listening to it. That this often happens in disputed territories.

The reason why their lack of response to this argument was so alarming is because even if we concede all the harms and benefits, this is how the comparative comes out. Because if this is a debate about the kinds of incursion

that China will continue to have on either side, we don't understand why that's something that's unique on their side. Because their ideas were generic, that China wants that region, that it wants to claim that empire. But on the other hand, what they actually did was to empower China to unleash this incursion upon the entire world.

When they could hold nations in Africa and Europe subject to their net. When they could violate their sovereignty. And it internationally hastened this destruction by putting the entire world at the subject of China. So they wanted to talk about the comparative. Their side was the side that hastened the kind of destruction in the very, very worst case. Then they brought out lots of new material in thought opposition, when they tell you that there's going to be a race to the bottom because otherwise conditionally it is bad, now it gets better. What they failed to recognize is the comparative is a world

where different actors check each other. The United States holds debt in Chinese money and therefore checks China, and China is actively participating in international institutions. It is Xi Jinping's legacy to make China boredom like they say. And at the same time, regional powers hold all of these actors accountable. Therefore, it was an as simplistic a debate as side opposition wanted to push the EU. But their conception of this debate was very simple. It's that there isn't money, so we need money. What they didn't realise is that bad debt is worse than no debt at all. The kinds of crippling effects that come with default when your ports are stripped away and you're left with long-term poverty is far more worse.

But what did China conceive? They conceived a self-interest. They conceived that China empowers dictators, but they don't respond to our second speaker's material on how they target dictators, profit from the sustenance of dictators. And how the comparative is one where strongmen can be liberalized by holding them accountable, using it as a leverage. They concede that the OB over has failed so far and that Kenya doesn't have power against China.

They just say alternatives are worse with no clarification of what these alternatives are or why they will happen. Let's look at their alternative of war. They say China has an incentive for peace, but apparently there will be war. An incentive for internal struggles being reduced, but apparently war reduces internal struggles. Global image, but apparently that's good in war. There's an internal surplus, but apparently that's also good in a world with war. If they wanted to talk about bilateral ties, they fail to realize that this is a question of do we want bilateral aid, do we want multilateral aid, or do we want debt?
Even if this debate is about China, by 2042, India will have a greater population. If it's just one rule, it's a dead end, we think that we need to loosen the belt.

title: Macau Online WSDC 2021 Quarter Finals 2 (Malaysia vs Singapore)
description:
This House regrets the Westernization of the elites in post-colonial countries
Prop: Malaysia
Opp: Singapore

Opp wins
motion: This House regrets the Westernization of the elites in post-colonial countries

argument_units.text: The westernization of elites leads to the degradation of respect in our own culture and identities, forever entrenching post-colonial states as inferior to our western counterparts.

The set-up from proposition is threefold. Firstly, we regret the westernization of elites. We would rather than, elites post and during colonialism, stay within your own country, keeping their wealth and influence within these countries to build out, for example, local education system and local institutions. Secondly, on opposition, the westernization of elites looks like them traveling to the UK and to other western states to live, to work, to study, all because they prefer the culture in those areas and because they prefer those societies. Lastly, we say when we're talking about post-colonial states, these are often states that are still rebuilding and they have the active incentive to build a functioning state. We would say Western institutions aren't the only ones that work. We can have institutions that are specifically tailored to these individuals, to those cultures. For example, we still have public education, but instead of 40 students all reading pro-colonialism propaganda in one classroom, it is tailored to the multicultural setting of these countries. Democracy in the United Kingdom, for example, was based on a racially homogenous society versus our kind of society is one that's built on having multiracial identities within the society.

Two arguments then to forward from proposition. Firstly, on why it's principally egregious to be compliant in a system of oppression. Secondly, on how this leads to the degradation of development of state institutions. The first argument, the principle, three parts here. Number one, colonialism was an oppressive structure imposed onto every post-colonial state, involving ruthless divide and conquer of our society, pillaging our land of resources, our potential to build cultural erasure and erasing the identities we hold true to our hearts. This is something that's objectively wrong and we should objectively oppose. But the rhetoric on opposition is that these Western ideas are fair, that these institutions are good. They excuse all of the abhorrence when we welcome those institutions as something we should mimic and something we should replicate. In the status quo, it is already extremely difficult for developing nations to get compensation for the horrors of colonialism. Opposition makes it far worse. Secondly, we say elites are a culturally normative force. They hold positions of power. They hold wealth. For example, when they're political or financial leaders within the country, people automatically associate them with success. Therefore, in opposition, individuals associate these elites with success, with Western culture, with Western languages, with Western religion, like Christianity. On opposition, you idealize everything associated with them, idealizing then these Western ideals. Why is it so principally abhorrent, the third layer of this argument? Because what opposition does is idealize Western cultures at the expense of our own by putting Western culture on a pedestal. We say the purpose of independence post-colonialism is autonomy over your identity and over yourself. But what opposition does is impose this idea that many post-colonial states lose the basis of their culture and the key to self-actualization, the roots of their identity. When you view your mother tongue as unimportant and when you view, for example, speaking Chinese as something that's not going to make you successful, you have internalized feelings of inferiority under your side of the house. This empowers the colonial colonizers' rhetoric that they came to our countries and civilized us by bringing us humanity devaluing our value as individuals saying we only have importance because of the west this argument is independently principled i should be allowed to feel proud in my mother tongue and my religion of western imposition without feeling failing because i am not subscribing to their ideals of what successful is. But before I go on, I'll take that point. Given that elites tend to overwhelmingly come from one ethnic group, why is it that your likely comparative is one of multi-racialism rather than promoting the narratives of the ethnic group the elite come from? We think that when elites stay within the country, there's a higher probability of them interacting with different racial groups. Under your side of the house, we'd be bringing an elitist and a kind of view that doesn't take into consideration any of the suffering of anyone within the country on a scale we are far better for people within these countries the second argument on how this leads to the degradation of the development of state institutions also in three parts firstly we see the westernization of elites in the past and trench western norms for decades for example we see our final goal as replicating their system and their system to be the one that is best. After assigning ideas of success with the west for generations, we always feel our system is inferior. This leads to harm and impacts the institutions of states in two ways. Firstly, how this harms local education systems in two ways as well. Firstly, we say the reason why local education systems in post-colonial states like ours is developed so slowly is because elites leave and they don't come back. They don't build up local institutions because a bad local education system doesn't affect them when they know they're just going to move to Harvard because they perceive that to be a more successful institution. On our side of the house, when they stay within the countries, when they invest their time and money into it, this creates investment into the local education system. If you attend local universities, you will give endowments. Your success as an individual in a position of power, for example, an elite is more likely to be successful, gives credence to the success of the university, which begets even more smarter minds to enter these universities. It is a vicious cycle that elevates the intellect of everyone in society that opposition never gets. Local universities are important to make education accessible to everyone. Opposition exacerbates the wealth gap, for example, when wealthy individuals can achieve education and can achieve quality education when local institutions are never meaningfully developed under their side of the house. Secondly, they have brain drain on opposition. This looks like post-conflict. They need the brightest mind and the highest capital in order to develop. These nations have nascent government structures. They don't have wealthy coffers, for example, to kick off innovation and new industries. Therefore, you're relying on your local talent pool in order to develop and grow as a country. On opposition, this never happens because these individuals leave and they don't return because you don't even develop the local institutions. But if opposition wants to say that these elites will come back and they will bring with them ideas that help the country grow, we have two things to say. Firstly, we don't think the West is the only way for you to be able to achieve success and development. But secondly, we say that these individuals are likely not to return. Your wealthy individual will go to, for example, the UK, form connections overseas, have memories and lived experiences there. And after the entrenchment of Western ideals that say that those societies are superior, they're going to stay there, they're going to bring their wealth and influence there, and you will never meaningfully develop your countries. This is why education institutions in countryside hours like Malaysia are so underdeveloped because of this idealization of the West. The last part of this argument is about how this impacts the political system. And this directly clashes with your POI on how we get more inclusive systems. We see that your political systems will never fit the people on the ground for three reasons. Firstly, because those in charge of nation building, for example, the elite, don't know the context of the people there. For example, you went to boarding school in the UK, you have no idea the racial tensions in the country. You have no idea that people need, for example, welfare. You just want to bring ideas of like fiscal conservatism from the country that you came from. But secondly, we see the imposition of things like the common law, for example, from the UK is not fit for locals. The system of land ownership with indigenous individuals versus that of the United Kingdom was vastly different. Imposing Christianity over local cultures, these are things that individuals don't want, don't need, and we think that you should not support under their side of the house. But lastly, we would rather have, for example, quotas under our side

of the house for different racial groups. We get our own form of government that's representative of everyone because everyone wants to build a country. But for example, the West would never allow this kind of quota system because that's unlikely to be democratic. This means that there

are systems who never fit the local populations. And when you impose a failing system, this just creates more tension when it is a system that is in contention with the local population and with their moral compasses. When we perceive the West as our only path to survival, we forcefully impose a failing system onto countries who will never get the chance to develop. Change has to be organic, change has to be natural. We don't support the westernization of the elites. Proud to propose. Wonderful, thank you very much. First proposition for those very fine remarks. To open the case from the opposition side of the house in this debate, inviting the first speaker from that bench to deliver their speech.

I prefer verbal. Thank you. The case of team proposition is hinged on the one line in first that they have a multicultural society. If this is not true, then all of their argumentation about the harms of cultural hierarchy, the imposition of one culture upon all minorities, apply to them as well. Notice they give you absolutely no reason why this multicultural society is a likely comparative, and given that this motion is retrospective, they have no fiat to do so. There are a few reasons why this is unlikely to be the comparative. First, because the elites in many of these countries are ethnically homogenous. As a result of colonial divide and rule tactics, where colonizing powers designate one ethnicity to rule in their place after they leave or during the period of colonization, these elites on their side of the house that shape society and shape governance overwhelmingly come from an ethnically dominant and majority class that is not representative of the entire society.

For example, the Tutsis in Rwanda were designated by the British colonizers as their vice regents in that country. They therefore have an incentive to propagate their majority culture on their side of the house, meaning that all of the harms of cultural imposition apply to them as well. They have no case. Who are these elites that we are talking about? Elites, as I mentioned, are traditionally concentrated among one ethnic group. For instance, the Sikhs in Indian civil service or the Indonesian Chinese under Dutch colonization in Indonesia. This means that privilege is largely inherited along racial lines.

What is our stance on opposition? We do not regret the westernization of elites in post-colonial countries. The burden on proposition is not just to show that westernization is harmful, but that it would have been worse than any other counterfactual. They have to structurally prove on the absence of this westernization, their comparative would occur. This debate, importantly, is not about regretting the presence of elites. This debate is specifically about whether they should be westernized or not. On their side, there are still elites. The likely comparative is that they would have imposed in their own racial culture. For instance, the Burmese government, composed largely of Burman elites,

imposed the Burmese language and Buddhist religion on the Christian Karen and Shan people. We have three arguments on opposition. First, that westernization avoids ethnic conflict. Second, that westernization allows for political dissent. And my second speaker will prove how westernization improves foreign relations. Let's first take a look at

Proposition's case. They first tell us that colonialism is bad and therefore westernization is bad. First, they tell us that western ideas are seen as superior to those of your local country. This is not true because this argument assumes that western culture is only concentrated among western people and their descendants in these post-colonial countries. As I'll show you later in my first argument, this is not true and therefore this idolization does not occur. Second, they say Western ideas inherently propagate colonialism, whereas local ideas don't. This is just untrue. Many of the anti-colonial narratives that led to the downfall of colonialism were propagated in Western societies and Western universities. For example, Ho Chi Minh was educated in Paris and brought those anti-colonial ideas back to Vietnam. Finally, they say there is cultural inferiority on out of the house. This is going to be the same on their side. When there is cultural inferiority on the House. This is going to be the same on their side. When there is cultural inferiority between the minority and majority communities in the country, they have to prove why that is better. No, thank you. Second, they say the development of local societies hindered on us at the House.

First, they tell us education systems are hindered because Western elites overwhelmingly go overseas. The reasons for brain drain are largely unrelated to this motion. If these elites want to move overseas, Isagenix is likely because they think they can lead a better life overseas, regardless of the kind of culture they have. Moreover, their comparative assumes that there are no poor, rich geographical divides in local countries. The likely comparative on their side is a brain drain from rural areas to urban areas, where these urban cities are overwhelmingly developed with their local universities and rural areas are still left out. So their comparative is not any better. Second, they say a brain drain is likely to occur. No, these elites are unlikely to stay in the West precisely because they are elites in your local context. Within your local country, they have overwhelming social and economic influence, which they don't have overseas. If, for instance, no thank you, elites from Nigeria move to the UK, they don't have that kind of overwhelming social influence in the UK, thereby creating an incentive for them to remain in Nigeria. come back to this point in reply speaker since we gave it in first. Hence, all of the accusations that proposition gives to us as to why English is inequitable are out because we have proven that it is an equitable system of governance. For all of these reasons, I'm proud to oppose.

Panel, I don't know at what point this debate became about learning English, but it was clearly about when it was about imposing moral superiority over individuals and having cultural erasure. Some of the opposition could not win this debate because they were not charitable. They did not want to make trade-offs. But also, this could not be weighed up against the complete lack of engagement to our arguments about literally eroding local values and cultures. No, this is not a specific context. You're a country where it's had hundreds of years of a past of feeling inferior to a specific racial group. title: Macau Online WSDC 2021 Quarter Finals (Canada vs China)
description:
Motion: This House objects to the giving of international military aid
Proposition: Canada
Opposition: China

Prop wins
motion: This House objects to the giving of international military aid

argument_units.text: Thanks. International military aid is merely throwing fuel into a raging fire. On proposition, we believe that this aid becomes the battleground of international tensions and worsens the conflicts that it claims to resolve. A few things I'll do in my speech. First, I'll model the debate. Then I'll talk about why this aid leads to more war. Secondly, I'll talk about why military aid leads to harmful leverage that prolongs conflict.

Three points of setup. Firstly, that military aid is monetarily assisting the government of a country in its military efforts, either maintaining control or in self-defense. So this might look like giving them money to buy guns and tanks from PMCs like Lockheed Martin in the US. Instances like maintaining control or self-defense are not black and white. Self-defense can look like bloody wars or cracking down on protesters could look like maintaining control. These are situations that are fair game in this debate. Second point of setup, this debate is not about things like peacekeeping, joint training ventures, or intelligence sharing mechanisms. We are perfectly fine with these things, so we are not leaving these countries alone. We just oppose the unaccountable and inflammatory method of international military aid. And then finally, this debate is not just about the US giving aid. Countries like Russia, China, and Saudi Arabia give a ton of international military aid too. Opposition must contend with the states who don't necessarily have the best incentives. On our side, we prefer a world where no states give international military aid.

On my first point then about more war. So there are two reasons why the states who give military aid often give it poorly, even if they don't actively have malicious incentives. Firstly, these states often prioritize consolidating their strategic alliances, not necessarily focusing on good or humane military objectives. And this is because the donors of aid are far away from the conflict. They're very insulated from it. So they don't necessarily have a direct interest in whether people who are a thousand miles away or very different from you ethnically and religiously are dying. Instead, this aid is often prioritized to strategic locations because that is an impact that actively manifests in your country's politics. For example, the U.S. funds Israel because it's the one democratic country in a sea of Middle Eastern countries, or Russia and Belarus are quite close because Belarus is a staunch ally of Putin. This means instead of caring about humanitarian ends, as opposition might claim, this aid is often effectively unconditional because that alliance matters more than the result of the conflict. Secondly, on economic interests. So the Israel lobby in the US, oil interests in Saudi Arabia, Turkish control over the Black Sea and wanting to have access to the Black Sea often means that you give aid to some countries that are strategically important to you over others. You want to curry their favor and establish control within those areas. So instead of this aid going to states who are actually vulnerable, you prioritize the countries that can help your country the most. Why is this aid going to escalate conflict then? There are four reasons for this. Firstly, because there's a lack of accountability. So the recipients of this aid are often quite unstable just by the nature of the motion, like they are in a conflict, so they need the aid in the first place. This often translates into there being a lack of democratic checks or legitimacy to the government, things like ethnic divisions within the country. This means that the government that uses this aid is both unaccountable, but often uses this aid poorly and has the incentive to use it to entrench its own power. So this looks like Israel using US aid to bomb Palestinian villages, Maduro using Russian aid to roll tanks down the streets and quash protesters. The second reason why this aid will escalate conflict is because you give them more sophisticated weaponry. This is just definitionally true, given that you're receiving money from rich countries and you're now able to buy weapons from their companies. So instead of pistols, you now have machine guns. And even in opposition's best cases with things like terrorism, terrorists are notoriously hard to find, especially with the lack of intelligence gathering mechanisms, which is often the case in these poorer countries. The only addition with international military aid then is that you get more bombs to throw around that kill civilians, that rip families apart, that turn hospitals to rubble. And those are far more sophisticated and destructive. The third reason this point is true is because this funding is two-sided. So there are international rivalries that often manifest in proxy conflicts. China and the US butt heads in the South China Sea by funding opposing countries. The US and Russia fund opposing sides in the war in Syria. This means that it's not just giving money to one side that they can then use this money to just stop the conflict. You are highly unlikely to end the conflict at all because both sides get bankrolled. And so they just clash against each other and that conflict gets worse and worse. The final mechanism here is that you have no incentive to negotiate and actually have an end to the conflict. To come to the table, both sides need to be vulnerable. They need to be unable or unwilling to withstand the economic costs of that conflict anymore. So both sides are like, let's come together and put an end to this. But when you are both being bankrolled by different wealthy countries who seemingly have unending reserves of cash, there is no cost to this conflict or not as great of a cost. So you are then just showing weakness when the other side is being paid and you are saying, let's negotiate. This means that countries have no incentive to come to the table and conflicts go on and on. International military aid merely adds fuel to the fire and causes more death and suffering. But for my second point, I'll take the POI. The premise of your argument is that these countries only care about strategic partnerships when giving aid. If that is true, why are they likely to give humanitarian efforts or share intelligence in a mannerism that helps the most vulnerable on your side of the house? No, no, no. Don't let opposition make this debate into either you fund entirely one thing or entirely the other. We are saying that states incentives primarily align with strategic objectives. So the states that are strategically important to you will receive more aid and receive it more often, which means the scale of the harm is greater. Of course, there might be isolated instances where there's humanitarian aid, but this debate needs to be one of weighing. Second point

then about why military aid leads to harmful leverage. The prior point talks about cases where the aid is given by countries without malicious incentives, which is opposition's best case. This point is about the very real cases where countries want conflict. So these are different situations. The two arguments aren't tense. Opposition must contend with this point as well, instead of engaging in a very narrow framework. The characterization here is that the states who have the money to give military aid, while the recipients become dependent on that aid because they need that aid to resolve their conflict, have huge amounts of leverage over the countries that receive that aid. There are two problems that manifest here. Firstly, that these states often have an active incentive to create conflict. This looks like religious incentives, like wanting to expand the influence of your particular sect of Islam, or wanting control over strategically important regions, such as being able to get more control through creating instability, which precludes other countries from getting involved or just knocks other countries out of the area. So this looks like Qatar, who funds the central government of Somalia, while the UAE and Saudi Arabia fund other regions like Somaliland instead, because both actors want control over the Red Sea shipping routes. This means that these actors end up clashing within the country, where Qatar's military aid goes towards bombing other regions of the country for their own power trip and to kick Saudi Arabia out while entire villages go up in rubble. The second problem here is that aid often creates loyalty, which is harmful. So elites are given power and often enriched by the aid that they receive. Corruption is common in these countries, and there's often little accountability by a state that is embroiled in war, especially when the other side is bankrolled too. There's no incentive to back down. These actors actively want to keep being involved in the conflict because it benefits them. They're receiving a continuous stream of cash. So this looks like Russia funding the Belarusian government's ability to buy arms in order to get closer access to Crimea in order to resist NATO influence in Eastern Europe. So when Russian troops are now able to move more freely within the Belarusian border, this increases the chance of conflict reoccurring, and it extremely harms pro-democracy efforts around the world. On proposition, we believe that military aid can be abused and is actually counterproductive to its aims. International military aid donors claim to be firefighters, but in reality, they're the arsonists. I'm so proud to propose.

The nature of aid is that it goes to those with no alternatives we are very proud to oppose. Two arguments in this speech. Firstly, why we protect the most vulnerable actors, and secondly, why we are better than the comparative. But before that, I think there are a

couple things to point out about the proposition case. The first is that they've given us no stance, no comparative about what they want to do in this debate. Would they allow Assad to use chemical warfare with no impunity on their side of the house. What type of accountability they think that the global police of America have in terms of groups that are being bombed, that are being threatened by authoritarian regimes. What does their intervention look like? Do you have to tell us that these people are going to pull out entirely or they're going to rely entirely on UN peacekeeping or they have to take a harder stance and support sending in troops on the ground? Secondly, they have not reached a burden in this debate because while they can prove a

multiplicity of incentives, while they can prove a multiplicity of characterizations and examples, they need to tell us why the specific mechanism of military aid is in and of itself so harmful. Certain examples don't win them that burden because this pertains to the sovereignty,

this pertains to the mechanisms of a government on a whole to be able to manage their international relations, and they need to tell us as to why they take out this tool in the toolbox and why it is so uniquely different to all the other ways that governments insert their international dominance on the global stage. Given that, I think there's a very clear thing

to say about the characterization of the comparative in this debate. That is to say, proposition cannot make out arms deals so that guns and bombs can still be bought on their side of the house. What that means then is that when they talk about actors such as authoritarian governments, when they talk about actors like terrorism, it is very likely that these individuals and groups will still be buying arms on both sides of the house. Why is this the case? Because authoritarians are rich. They often have a huge amount of resources, which is why they're able to put down their oppression towards their people because they have, for example, money that they spend on the military. Authoritarians have control over industrialization, which means that they can start producing guns and arms instead and start buying guns instead of having them as aid. And terrorism, for example, can have money through the black market, like the way that the Taliban sells heroin, or they can employ child soldiers and other ways of grassroots levying arms on their side of the house. So they have to tell us necessarily how these dangerous actors are stopped from getting dangerous weapons when individual aid pulls out. That being said, the comparative in this debate is about vulnerable actors who don't have the money, don't have the capital, don't have the resources and infrastructure to have military assistance when that aid pulls out. Firstly, then, why do we protect vulnerable actors? What do these actors look like? Firstly, it looks like in post-conflict societies that are ravaged by insurgents. It looks like South Sudan who deals with Janjaweed, who are killing innocent civilians. It looks like Ser post-conflict societies that are ravaged by insurgents. It looks like South Sudan who deals with Janjaweed, who are killing innocent civilians. It looks like Serbian extremists in Kosovo who want to kill the Albanian ethnicity group there. title: Macau Online WSDC 2021 Octo Finals 3 (China vs the Netherlands)
description:
Motion: This House supports periodic, fixed-date constitutional conventions in constitutional democracies
Proposition: China
Opposition: The Netherlands

Prop wins

argument_units.text: Thank you so much for that display of globalism.

On our side of the house, what we do is we force discussion. This House supports periodic, fixed-date constitutional conventions in constitutional democracies

Opp wins

title: Macau Online WSDC 2021 Octo Finals 1 (Sri Lanka vs Canada)
description:
Motion reads: THS periodic, fixed-date constitutional conventions in constitutional democracies
Prop: Sri Lanka
Opp: Canada

Opp wins
motion: This House supports periodic, fixed-date constitutional conventions in constitutional democracies

argument_units.text: Great, good. Panel, constitutional democracies are not democracies if they do not have democratic constitutions. That is the sense that we take on side proposition. The problem we face right now in Citus School
is that constitutions remain old documents, that they remain documents that tend to be inalterable, except for ad hoc amendments that occur once in a blue moon,

that require loads of bureaucracy. And even after you have achieved said bureaucracy, it is not guaranteed that you will get enough votes to get that change. In the absence of this, social movements have had to defer to other methods of change, like the legislature, in order to ensure that their needs are met. Individuals that want to secure their personal freedoms cannot do so through the best method possible, that is to say the constitution. They have to instead go through other methods like passing individual laws. We think that this world is one

in which social change and democracy is inhibited by the fact that it is just too slow. That is why we propose this motion. On counterfactual, how does the world change? There are two key differences that both sides are going to have to concede in this motion. Firstly, the immediacy in degree of change is higher on-site proposition. The reason for this is that amendments can only amend a specific change to the constitution. In that, you either put up a new amendment, you change the wording of an old amendment, or you strike that amendment entirely. On-site proposition, what you are allowed to do is rewrite the entire constitution. What this means is that the people in charge, that is to say delegates, have to go through every single part of the constitution and either have to approve it, strike it down or make an amendment to it. So the immediacy in degree of change is higher. Two, frequency is higher. Because in order to have a discussion of amendments, you need a large degree of public pressure because of the lack of a fixed time that everyone adheres to. When we on our side have a fixed time, the public knows when the change is going to happen, and thus it is regular. Opposition has to do both the actions of getting people into a convention and then also getting that amendment passed. Those are the two big differences that will occur once this motion goes through. Second thing then, in terms of delegates, we're talking about elected representatives or individuals in legislative bodies. The important thing to note is that these are people that individuals have consented into the representation of them because you vote them in to power. The most preferable option of pushing for constitutional change than in our world is likely to be that of the Constitutional Convention because it is the most frequent option. We recognize a trade-off in this debate in that we are likely to have fewer ad hoc amendments, but those come in favor of pushing those same ideas through in the form of constitutional change in the Constitution. For my arguments, sure. How often will these fixed periods be in effect? It will be roughly every election cycle. I don't know whether it will be on the election cycle, but roughly once every election cycle. First argument then as to why we are better able to get constitutional reform and why we get better forms of constitutional reform on our side. The context in this argument is to recognize that there is a significant time gap between the writing of a constitution and its implementation. Because in many, and thus in many instances, constitutions do not reflect the social attitudes of status quo. They reflect the social attitudes of when they were written. In the United States, the Constitution reflects the views of white rich men that own land in the 1700s. And because society is constantly changing, there is a necessity to reform the Constitution. The problem right now is that there is a massive barrier to entry in achieving that reform, because you need both political capital in order to call a vote, as well as the ability to overcome bureaucratic barriers to exist. Thus, on site opposition, there is a higher threshold needed to enact constitutional change. The problem is that that is disproportionately used by powerful parties parties because they are the ones that have agenda setting capacity, not just because they have the most votes, but also because they have things like incumbency advantage, because they are able to have other bureaucratic factors that give them a greater degree of power in being able to set up barriers to entry. Comparatively, we are better because we can see that in either world, opposition parties are going to be a minority. But at least in our world, we are able to get discussion of these issues in the first place. Thus, the marginal change you are able to receive is greater in our world. This is a debate-winning argument because the core reason you have a constitution is to enshrine the ability of people to represent themselves through change. secondly it's comparatively better because voters themselves feel better able to change the constitution when they realize that they have a greater degree of change in being able to do so when it becomes a voting priority that you are able to elect people that directly change the constitution second level under this argument is as to why we get greater public scrutiny of amendments because the problem with ad hoc amendments is that there is often a sense of urgency when they are proposed and thus they because they come about as a swell of public pressure thus there is very little time for the public to either understand the importance of it or for parties to rally sufficient support of it. Thus, even when you do have amendments, there's often very little scrutiny of them and thus they end up either being vague or shallow. Comparatively, we are better because the constitutional convention creates a greater pressure to make change when you are forced to take a stance on every single amendment and thus we are able to force for greater degrees of change in the amendments. The problem here then lies in social movements and that is the third part of this argument because in the absence of being able to read the constitution, the social movements in society are forced to defer to other methods of getting change. The main way they do so is through the legislature and doing things like passing law. This looks like the passing of Roe versus Wade. The problem with this is that it is very unstable because they can easily be reversed through other votes in the legislature.
For example, Roe versus Wade would easily be overturned

if Amy Coney Barrett said that she wanted to. Comparatively, even though minorities have no guarantee of success on either side of the house, on our side, when they have the political capital to be able to get that change, instead of channeling it into the legislature, they channel it into a constitutional change, which means that when we do get change, it is more stable. Second argument is why we get better political accountability. Two levels. Firstly, because we are better able to correct for institutional weakness, because in many constitutions, there are old documents that are open to interpretation, and thus are interpreted in ways that are beneficial to the political establishment. This looks like the interpretation of free speech laws as allowing for almost infinite amounts of campaign spending. The problem with this is that it creates a collective action problem in that these forms of clauses are beneficial to all parties and thus the issues do not become, are not even discussed in the first place. Thus, politicians can skirt accountability by never even discussing the issues and thus are never forced to take a stance. Comparatively, we are better because when politicians are forced to vote on every part of the constitution, they are forced to take a stance. This is more transparent to voters who now know exactly what part of the constitution their elected representative supports. Thus, if they do not want their representative in favor of things like extra campaign funding, they are later able to actually vote in an individual who opposes those ideologies. Secondly, is that we create an image change in that the constitution is no longer seen as a sacred document. Right now, politicians leverage the perception of the constitution as one that is a sacred document to prevent change in putting it up on a pedestal. In our world, the constitution is not only a document that can be changed regularly, it is one that should be. This means that individuals have a greater capacity in fighting for their rights through the best method of doing so. Because we make sure that constitutional democracies and democratic constitutions propose.
