The constitution is our protection against the majority and the ebbs and flows of politics. On opposition, we believe that conventions both undermine the purpose of constitutions and hamper political progress.

A few things I'll do in this debate. First, I'll set up opposition stance, then I'll rebut the Gov case. Then I'll talk about why the politicization of the Constitution opens the door to abuse. And secondly, why this convention comes at a huge political opportunity cost.

So first on some stance, we prefer amendments instead. The difference between amendments and constitutions is twofold. Firstly, that amendments organically arise via political preferences. So for example, an MP proposes an amendment, you are not forced to relook the constitution every couple of years. But secondly, there's a much higher bar to get those amendments passed. For example, in Canada, it is a super majority in parliament and then a referendum vote. When you are talking about whether individuals have rights, we don't think proposition can say bureaucracy is bad in this case. Presumably, there should be a ton of barriers when you're talking about whether or not people have the right to live. We stand for a constitution that serves its purpose to enshrine rights without being susceptible to abuse. On rebuttal then, so firstly, proposition makes a differentiation between amendments and like this convention via the frequency and scope of change. I don't think this is sufficient differentiation. Like, I don't think it's a good thing that when the like, sure, the amendment might be outdated in some respects. But why not just make an amendment towards that specific clause than looking at every single other clause that happens to be good when the next guy can easily change it back when they're also talking about the frequency of change. Them justifying this by saying the Constitution was written by rich men is insufficient insofar as, yes, there might be some clauses we change, but we amend those when those rich men also enshrined our right to life, to a fair trial, to liberty and the security of person. I don't know why we need to look at everything else. Then they say that constitutions can be changed and that's a good thing. Four responses to this. Firstly, constitutions are fundamentally not supposed to be democratic. Laws are supposed to be democratic. The constitution is supposed to challenge the rule of the majority. If the majority wants to take away your rights, if they want to vote for a politician again and again and again, that's where term limits come in, in the constitution. That's where you say that you can't discriminate against people. We don't think that democracy should be the fundamental point of the constitution. Secondly, though, on scrutiny, this point is just a lie. Like if the constitution has existed for 200 years, why is there urgency now? If the constitution is so important, why don't you take your time? The Meech Lake Accord in Canada that attempted to change the constitution took months. And that's because you have far more scrutiny when there's only one amendment that happens only once every couple of years. People pay more attention to it. We went on scrutiny. Thirdly, constitutions and laws are for different purposes. This isn't a trade-off. The constitution, it's the structure of the government and the limitations. Laws are for specific things. Lastly, I don't know what this thing about politicians being forced to take a stance on issues mean. Presumably you learn what a politician's stance is through debate on votes and the part where they're actually running for office, where they have to explain their stance to get elected.

First point then about politicization of the Constitution. Firstly, I'd like to frame that constitutions are already quite good at enshrining basic rights. Note that proposition couldn't give any illustrations as to why, like, a time that we need to change the constitution to improve the rights of the minority. That's because they're already quite good at it. Three reasons for this. Firstly, structurally, they're designed to enshrine limitations on the state's power to protect minority rights versus the majority by putting a cap on what the powerful can do. Secondly, amendments require a lot of support. So when you amend the constitution, it has to be extremely broadly popular and cross party lines. That's why amendments aren't just all shot down because of the bureaucratic system that prop hates. It's like past amendments such as women being able to vote in the United States or the 14th Amendment that created anti-discrimination in the Constitution. Those types of things were passed through amendments or things like the selfish aims of politicians aren't. Thirdly, there's something called analogous grounds in constitutional laws where existing rights imply other rights. So even if we don't specifically have a right to water, the right to life implies that, and the right to food and all of the right to life entails. The right to security of person was used in the debate in favor of abortion, meaning that even if we don't have specific things in the constitution, they can already be accessed through court interpretation. This breaks the deadlock in the debate then. Constitutions are good at protecting people, but these rights can easily be taken away.

Three mechanisms as to why states can abuse the constitutional convention. Firstly, there's a pressure to make changes every time this convention happens because politicians want to do something. Like even if you inherit a good economy, you are still expected to pass things. Parliament getting held up for a month, like debating the constitution and not having anything to show for it will lead to huge backlash, meaning politicians will make up issues where they don't exist. Secondly, this is subject to short-term democratic cycles. They talk about Roe v. Wade. Roe v. Wade could be overturned by like a conservative politician. This is because politicians can rile up their base around constitutional issues. The sentiment of the current political party can be applied to the committee that they appoint. So a tough-on-crime administration or a transitional democracy with a power-hungry government can change the constitution in its favor. Thirdly, on political horse trading and lobbying. So of course, this is everywhere in politics, but it's worse than the Constitution in two reasons. Firstly, constitutional law is more consequential as proposition concedes. But secondly, the stakes are much higher for lobbyists because the Second Amendment is existential for the NRA. And this is because the only way to get things passed is to make concessions in Parliament to other parties. So the Constitution will probably be a big deal to lots of political parties and will become the focus of negotiations, which means there's lots of political horse trading, lots of lobbying, which means that it's actually not as democratic as proposition states. What are the impacts of this then? Governments can abuse the constitution to do things that they want. title: Hungary vs USA WSDC 2018 Round 2
description:
The decision in this debate was a 3-0 win for the USA.

The motion: This House opposes the development of lethal autonomous weapons. 

Info slide: lethal autonomous weapons are a type of autonomous military robot designed to select and attack military targets (people or installations) without intervention by a human operator.USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: This House Would Ban the Development of Lethal Autonomous Weapons.

title: WSDC 2018 R7: Estonia vs New Zealand
description:
TH regrets the Belt and Road initiative

Estonia PROP vs New Zealand OPP

3:0 New Zealand won
motion: This House regrets the Belt and Road Initiative.

argument_units.text: Now, I invite the first speaker from the side of the stage. Honourable panel, the Belt and Road Initiative is a Chinese immensely ambitious development strategy which purposes to control world trade and change the global power balance towards China. China plans to invest $900 billion into connecting the Eurasian and African countries with China through six land-based economic corridors and an ocean-going maritime support. This is done by investing into expensive infrastructure projects in other nations.

However, we have noticed that this is not a charity. For hosting nations, there are mainly two scenarios. Either the states find themselves in debt traps to the Chinese government, or if they have no hope of paying back alone, they would have to give away their infrastructure to China, ports, roads, railways, or even their territory. Both of these options are horrific, and Team Estonia is very proud to regret the Belt and Road Initiative. But let's let the filter into this Belt and Belt and Road Initiative. Most of these nations are emerging economies, and even without the Belt and Road Initiative, are experiencing economic growth and moving towards a positive direction. Ethiopia has 10% and Pakistan has 7% of GDP growth. And the same is in most of the nations that host the initiative. Now the growth means that they are fighting without Chinese investments in the long run and will likely build the same scale infrastructure with their own capital without taking loans and giving away their infrastructure just after 50 years or so. But notice that there are also other alternatives like international government banks or private capital that has always incentive to help the cheap workforce. So now our whole case for today is why the initiatives of HARP are much worse than waiting for these nations to get on their feet by themselves or with the help of other actors.

This debate is not from the perspective of China or the West, but rather this debate should be assessed from a global perspective. Today in my speech, firstly, I'm going to look at regional impacts, secondly, global impacts, and our second speaker will tell you about the risk, wealth, and road initiative. Before we move on to my first argument, do you think Donald Trump would provide better trade opportunities for Pakistan? We don't believe that China is the only one who is able to provide trade opportunities for the belt and road initiative. But notice that we don't regret China doing bilateral agreements with separate states, which states have the legitimacy to control them themselves. We just regret the initiative where these individual states have very little capability of deciding for themselves.

But now, let's get into our first argument, how the initiative affects the whole situation. States care mainly about two things, their sovereignty and their economic prosperity. Here are three reasons how the host nations' economies will be damaged. Firstly, China offers predatory loans to these nations, which means the high interest rates that drain these States' budget are in place. Now, China gave Sri Lanka a low interest rate of 6.3%, while the interest rate of the World Bank and the National Development Bank were only 3% for similar loans. So the unfair loans make states directly poorer in the long run. Second way how it harms the economy is that China takes hold of their infrastructure and hence damaging them. Sri

for a hundred years due to great debt. Look, this means that Sri Lanka has spent a lot of money on the port and has now no benefit from it at all. China is currently bringing in her manufacturing groups, while the Sri Lankan economy actually needs raw materials so desperately. China also does this in other countries like Pakistan and Kazakhstan, and the states are earning more benefit from the infrastructure that they will build, hence leading them in debt just to serve the interests of another nation. Now, the very last reason of how their economy will be damaged is that the initiative influences local markets and manufacturers very negatively. The Belt and Road Initiative makes it key to Chinese growth and more accessible in these nations, which means that these nations' own products often can't compete and local sectors and companies are pushed out of the market. Madagascar's tech side industry suffered after China's company started exporting their own product into Madagascar through the Belt and Road Initiative. So their impact is that if you come close to China, the local people are left poor and jobless, even more than they were before the initiative.

I have shown you that this is destructive to their economy,. But let's look at how it affects their sovereignty. States are dependent on China and foreign governments and this limits their own decision making. Because Chinese people already influence their inner state decisions through the immense lobbying power that they have. Chinese business people lobby for their decisions and their interests. There are more of them due to the increased business of China now with the Belt and Road Initiative. And it was also the Chinese size of other issues in foreign policy. China can now influence other nations to support its actions in the territorial disputes because they are economically dependent on China. China offered development aid to Brunei and Laos so it could support its controversial actions, militarily seizing other nations' territories and assault China's sea in order for them to get development aid. So this means that small states are afraid of lagging behind China and hence they obey. So this allows more parts of China to exercise an aggressive foreign policy that before you had an incentive to do that right now.

But now, let me move on to my second argument that describes the global impacts of China expanding their power. Military expansion is an inherent part of the Belt and Road Initiative. The reason why China is willing to execute a project that's so expensive and yet likely to fail is because it enables them to expand their power militarily. Firstly, it raises tensions because political tensions and worries of other nations are very unlikely to support China's military expansion. Sure, I got your point. We believe that yes, the USA has already very many military bases. First I want to know why BRI countries are better off aligning themselves with China than with the West.
